verses.verse: Then I returned<WH7725> and saw<WH7200> all the oppressions<WH6217> that are done<WH6213> under the sun<WH8121>: and<WH1832>, behold, the tears of such as were oppressed<WH6231>, and they had no comforter<WH5162>; and on the side<WH3027> of their oppressors<WH6231> there was power<WH3581>; but they had no comforter<WH5162>.
Wherefore I praised<WH7623> the dead<WH4191> that have been<WH3528> long dead<WH4191> more than the living<WH2416> that are yet<WH5728> alive<WH2416>;
yea <WH2896>, better than them both<WH8147> did I esteem him that hath not yet<WH5728> been<WH7200>, who hath not seen the evil<WH7451> work<WH4639> that is done<WH6213> under the sun<WH8121>.

Then I saw<WH7200> all labor<WH5999> and every skilful<WH3788> work<WH4639>, that for this a man<WH376> is envied<WH7068> of his neighbor<WH7453>. This also is vanity<WH1892> and a striving<WH7469> after wind<WH7307>.
The fool<WH3684> foldeth<WH2263> his hands<WH3027> together<WH2263>, and eateth<WH398> his own flesh<WH1320>.
Better <WH2896> is a handful<WH3709>, with quietness<WH5183>, than two<WH2651> handfuls<WH4393> with labor<WH5999> and striving<WH7469> after wind<WH7307>.
Then I returned<WH7725> and saw<WH7200> vanity<WH1892> under the sun<WH8121>.

There is<WH3426> one<WH259> that is alone<WH8145>, and he hath not a second; yea<WH1121>, he hath neither son nor brother<WH251>; yet is there no end<WH7093> of all his labor<WH5999>, neither are his eyes<WH5869> satisfied<WH7646> with riches<WH6239>. For whom then<WH6001>, saith he, do I labor, and deprive<WH2637> my soul<WH5315> of good<WH2896>? This also is vanity<WH1892>, yea<WH7451>, it is a sore travail<WH6045>.
Two <WH8147> are better<WH2896> than one<WH259>, because they have<WH3426> a good<WH2896> reward<WH7939> for their labor<WH5999>.

For if they fall<WH5307>, the one<WH259> will lift up<WH6965> his fellow<WH2270>; but woe<WH337> to him that is alone<WH259> when he falleth<WH5307>, and hath not another<WH8145> to lift him up<WH6965>.
Again <WH1571>, if two<WH8147> lie together<WH7901>, then they have warmth<WH2552>; but how can one<WH259> be warm alone<WH3179>?
And if a man<WH259> prevail<WH8630> against him that is alone<WH8147>, two shall withstand<WH5975> him<WH8027>; and a threefold cord<WH2339> is not quickly<WH4120> broken<WH5423>.
Better <WH2896> is a poor<WH4542> and wise<WH2450> youth<WH3206> than an old<WH2205> and foolish<WH3684> king<WH4428>, who knoweth<WH3045> not how to receive admonition any more<WH2094>.
For out of prison<WH631> he came<WH3318> forth to be king<WH4427>; yea<WH4438>, even in his kingdom he was born<WH3205> poor<WH7326>.
I saw<WH7200> all the living<WH2416> that walk<WH1980> under the sun<WH8121>, that they were with the youth<WH3206>, the second<WH8145>, that stood up in his stead<WH5975>.

There was no end<WH7093> of all the people<WH5971>, even of all them over whom he was<WH6440>: yet they that come after<WH314> shall not rejoice<WH8055> in him<WH1892>. Surely this also is vanity and a striving<WH7475> after wind<WH7307>.
